column15: The Division of Arachnology was established in the year 1998 with the objective of conducting authentic studies on spiders of South India, especially in the state of Kerala. The division functions under the Department of Zoology of Sacred Heart College, Thevara, Cochin, Kerala, India. The following are the thrust areas of research--- Diversity of spider fauna in Kerala State, India; Spiders as biocontrol agents; Study of the feeding potential of spiders of paddy and vegetable agro-ecosystems and the effect of insecticides on spiders as part of integrated pest management; Behavioural study of jumping spiders of Kerala; Maintenance of reference collection of Kerala spiders.

column2: Arthropods of Medical Importance Resource Bank
column15: The activity of the AMIB (Arthropods of Medical Importance Bank) is to collect, cultivate, and systematically manage various kinds of arthropods and to supply them to the research institutes/companies. The Bank promotes a development of biomedicine, applied science and technology which are related with arthropods of medical importance. We provide a lot of study materials derived from arthropods of medical importance, including mite, cockroach, mosquito, and midges. Not only dried or immersed specimen of these samples but also crude extract and recombinant proteins of several species are now being provided to various research oriented facilities mostly in Korea. The AMIB has been established in the Institute of Tropical Medicine, Yonsei University College of Medicine since 1999 to provide research materials and to procure information for the research scientists and industries.

(=Frozen Lepidoptera Collection) Accumulated over 20+ years by Charles Mitter and his collaborators. Assembling the Tree Of Life Lepidoptera (ATOLep) collection currently contains ~16,000 specimens, representing 107 families, stored in 100% ethanol at -80 degrees C (suitable for both DNA PCR and RT-PCR). Not listed in any public database.

column2: Australian Biological Tissue Collection, South Australian Museum
column15: The Evolutionary Biology Unit (EBU) of the South Australian Museum (SAMA) maintains frozen and alcohol preserved tissues and DNA samples from approximately 120,000 vertebrate and invertebrate specimens. This collection, referred to as the Australian Biological Tissue Collection (ABTC), was the first such frozen tissue collection in any museum in Australia and one of the first two or three in the world. Today it is one of the largest wildlife tissue collections in the world. The collection encompasses most of the terrestrial vertebrate groups and a broad representation of major fish and invertebrate groups from Australia and surrounding regions. Each specimen receives a unique identifier and does not require a collection code. Alternate contact, inquireies for loans and accessibility: Dr. Terry Bertozzi Terry.Bertozzi@samuseum.sa.gov.au
Includes Arachnology, Entomology, Malacology, Marine Invertebrate, Herpetology, Ichthyology, Mammalogy, and Ornithology collections. All catalogued as one collection.

column15: In 1993, the herbarium collections, staff, databases, and research programs of the Australian National Botanic Gardens (CBG) were combined with those of the Australian National Herbarium (CANB) as part of the jointly managed and funded Centre for Plant Biodiversity Research.  CANB was adopted as the herbarium abbreviation for the combined collections.  Specimens originally from CBG will continue to be cited as CBG. The approximately 250 000 CBG specimens are included in the total for CANB. Information regarding CBG is included with CANB.  Correspondence, including loan requests, should be directed to CANB.

The Australian National Insect Collection (ANIC) is the world's largest collection of Australian insects and related groups such as mites, spiders, earthworms, nematodes and centipedes. ANIC is an important research collection used by CSIRO researchers, university staff and students, and scientists from Australian and international research organisations. There are over 12 million specimens housed in the Collection which is maintained by CSIRO Entomology in Canberra, in the Australian Capital Territory.
Australia's federal science agency, CSIRO, has four major natural history collections of which this is one.

column15: Bovine Genome Resources Bank (BGRB), one of the Korean National Research Resources Banks, is established to collect and maintain a variety of precious genetic and informative resources for bovine genome research. The constructed BGRB has genomic library, DNA samples from many cattle individuals, and eventually a well-organized computer-assisted database. BGRB will have positive contribution in scientific and economic field through collection and reservation of genome resources, support for the others researchers and provision of the useful tools to identify the genes with economically important traits for the improvement of the cattle production in the future. BGRB has a single collection that does not require collection codes.

The genus Brassica, phylogenetically related to Arabidopsis thaliana, is one of economically important crops and a botanical model of plant polyploidization and rapid phenotypic evolution. We established the Brassica Resource Bank (BRB) in order to supply basic plant materials for structural/functional genomics and breeding of Brassica. BRB has served various Brassica species, especially, doubled haploid and recombinant inbred lines, and DNA stocks including BAC libraries and cDNA libraries. BRB has collected specific-Brassica cultivars as well as subspecies from international plant resource centers. Moreover, all germplasms of BRB have been propagated and maintained. Currently, BRB has collected 9,591 accessions for Brassica species, 91,446 clones for cDNA libraries, and 277,440 clones for BAC libraries, and 1,398 genetic markers. BRB has served more than 621,345 clones, 280 genetic markers and 6,210 lines to researchers in 10 countries since 2003. Information and other requests for genomic resources of Brassica are accessible at http://www.brassica-resource.org.

They aimed for an organization fit to accommodate the sharing of their passion for the nature and to serve the dissemination of their discoveries in order to educate the younger generation in the spirit of knowledge about nature and of the preservation of natural trust.

column2: Canadian National Collection of Insects, Arachnids, and Nematodes
column15: The Canadian National Collection (CNC) of Insects, Arachnids and Nematodes is considered one of the best collections of its kind in the world in terms of size, species representation, and level of curation. It is maintained and developed by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada as part of its systematics research program, and is housed in the K.W. Neatby Building in Ottawa. The collection is estimated to contain approximately 16 million specimens systematically arranged in 1400 steel cabinets. Specimens are stored mostly as dry-mounted pinned specimens, but certain groups (e.g. larvae, aquatic insects, spiders, mites, aphids, midges, fleas, etc) are stored in liquid preservative or mounted on slides. The majority of specimens are from localities throughout Canada and North America, but significant holdings are present from other biogeographic regions.

column15: Center for Fungal Genetic Resources (CFGR) was established to collect, maintain, and distribute genetic resources from plant pathogenic fungi for fungal genetics community and educational and research organizations in general. A total of 35,000 isolates including 25,000 T-DNA transformants of rice blast fungus and anthracnose fungus have been deposited in the center to date. In addition to the biological materials, related information regarding genotype and genetic diversity is available for subscribers (e.g. such as ITS region sequence, SSR, Restriction fragment length polymorphism, and Amplified fragment length polymorphism). Genetic resources in the center will serve for researchers in understanding genetic diversity and structure of fungal populations as well as in characterizing the genetic mechanisms of fungal pathogenicity. These materials also can be applied in development of fungicides or disease-resistant cultivars and in preparation of quarantine standards.

The purpose of the bank is to develop and collect citrus genes, mutants and related materials that are essential for the research in breeding of citrus and other crops. Proper support systems including database will be established in the bank for maintenance and service of the collections (Maintenance and quality control systems for DNAs, Construction of database and update, Online/offline service systems, Collection of citrus mutants). We constructed EST library from the different citrus species and determined the EST sequences. From the analysis of gene, we found some abundant genes in the early stage of citrus fruit development. In addition, we also are collecting full-length cDNA and profiling the gene expression using the 3' and 5' RACE and DNA microarrays. The genes, materials and/or information are provided to anyone who researchers need for their research.

column15: The Cornell University Museum of Vertebrates (CUMV) is an internationally recognized institution dedicated to the study of vertebrates (fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals). It is an one of several natural history collections affiliated with Cornell University. The CUMV collections contain over 1.5 million specimens and serve as the primary repositories for vertebrates collected by past and present Cornellians doing research around the world. As a university based museum, it also serves as an important resource for undergraduate and graduate education. The CUMV is administered through the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology and the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell University. As a research institution, our specimens, tissue samples and related specimen data are available to qualified members of the scientific community affiliated with academic and research institutions. We especially encourage the use of the collections in student research, whether as thesis work, independent study, or class projects. Although there are no public exhibits at the museum, museum staff try to provide assistance to members of the Cornell Community whenever possible and do offer tours for classes and other interested groups.

Collection, archival collections from major inventory and assessment projects including several national parks and a PA National Guard Training Center and others.

The FGSC holds over 70,000 isolates of filamentous fungi including classical mutant, wild type, and gene deletion mutants for several fungi. Being a genetics repository, it emphasizes diversity of genetics and not diversity of organisms. Holdings include 48,000 Magnaporthe isolates, 20,000 Neurospora isolates, and several thousand Cryptococcus, Candida and Aspergillus strains.

column15: Previously used acronyms: GB, GGRB. Ginseng Resource Bank (GRB) is a scientific bank for collection and distribution of various resources related to ginseng, which includes ginseng seeds, transformed ginseng, varieties, regenerated plants, whole ginseng plants grown in field in Panax genus. GRB is preparing and providing genomic DNA, cDNA, EST and BAC library of ginseng. GRB is also providing related materials including ginsenoside saponin, ginseng publication list and literatures. GRB is hoping to construct database for ginseng research and to operate in the hub of ginseng world.

column15: Gujarat Biodiversity Gene Bank plays a vital role in conservation. This bank is primarily intended for the storage of DNA of endangered species and socio-economically important species of Gujarat. Gujarat Biodiversity Gene Bank also conserve Micro organisms. Gujarat Biodiversity Gene Bank is a multi-unit, multi-disciplinary, multi-institutional initiative with participating faculty, students, scientists and biotechnology industries. Activity focus is on Conservation Biotechnology operations including specialized research laboratories, training activities, infrastructure and equipment for the biotechnology community of Gujarat. Gujarat Biodiversity Gene Bank include conservation in terms of Seed banking and DNA Banking.

Updated Feb 2010. GH is fully integrated with A and AMES in the Harvard University Herbaria, but specimens from Gray Herbarium should be cited as GH. The 1 943 000 specimens in GH are included in the total given for the Harvard University Herbaria (listed under GH). The previously separate Harvard herbaria (A, AMES, ECON, FH, GH) were fully integrated in the 1980s and are now administered as a single unit. Although loans of vascular plants from the Harvard University Herbaria will include appropriate specimens from A, AMES, ECON, and GH, and also material from the New England Botanical Club Herbarium (NEBC), specimens cited in publications should use the standard abbreviations for each of those herbaria. Correspondence regarding specimens should not be sent to the separate institutions, but to huh-requests@oeb.harvard.edu. Work space can be provided for both long- and short-term visitors; written requests, especially for long-term visitors, should be sent to Emily Wood (ewood@oeb.harvard.edu). Also available for study are 50 000 paleobotanical specimens, 33 000 specimens of wood, 38 000 microscope slides of wood, 15 000 slides of other plant parts in the Bailey-Wetmore Wood Collection (Aw), and 11 000 pollen slides.

column15: The Natural History and Archaeology section assembles meaningful collections from which to interpret the history of life and environments, and cultures in Indiana. The museum has a strong program of field investigation and recovery. Collections are developed in three broad categories: Geology (strong in invertebrate fossils and late Pleistocene vertebrates), Biology, and Archaeology (with strong representation of select prehistoric and historic sites). There are some 500,000 items and lots in the collections.

column2: Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique - Orleans. Unite de Zoologie Forestiere
column15: The lab of Forestry Zoology studies the mechanisms underlying insect expansion caused by human activity and environmental changes, especially global warming. Research in: Genetics of native/non-native insects, biology of insect populations expanding with global warming or newly introduced in Europe, Mathematical modelling, prediction, risk assessment and management of insect invasions, Inventory of the alien invertebrates present in Europe and of potential insect invaders from Asia. Models include: processionary pine moth, horse chest nut leafminer, larch bud moth, Cone and seed insects, the endangered wild silk moth and the endangered populations of incense-juniper. All specimens are cataloged in a single numbering system and do not require collection codes.

Amphibians Collection is also the largest in the world as a group, including 122 holotypes and 153 paratypes. The collection also includes 10 holotypes Reptiles and 76 paratypes. Ichthyology Collection includes 1,300 species of fish in the country, including 610 species of freshwater fishes of the 800 registered at the national level. KEMB is established microbial and genetic resource center for environmental industries. Recently the demand of the microorganism is increasing according to the activation of environmental-industry. Collection and conservation of native environmental microorganisms (from water, soil, marine) and genetic resources. Construction of systematic management system for effective conservation and application of microbiological resources for environmental industries Promotion of research and industrial activity by utilizing environmental microbial and genetic resources Accomplishment of ecological recovery through constructing ecofriendly bioremediation system substituting chemical treatments by supplying basic microbial resources. There are 10,336 strains in the bank, including photosynthetic bacteria, xenobiotics degrading bacteria, nutrition salts degrading marine bacteria, odor degrading bacteria, and isolated bacteria from environments, materials, animals and humans. All specimens are kept in a single collection with a single numbering system and require no collection codes.

column2: Museu de Ciències Naturals de Barcelona
column15: The Martorell Museum, the original name of the current Museum of Natural Science, was built to house the collection bequeathed by Francesc Martorell i Pena (1822-1878) to the city of Barcelona in 1878. The first natural history collections accessioned into the Museum were those of Manuel Martorell, brother of the founder. The institution acquired its definitive 'naturalist' character within a few years of its founding when the archeology collections were transferred elsewhere. In second decade of the 20th century, the collections housed at the Museum of Catalonia (as it was called) were divided. As a result of this redistribution, the Martorell Museum acquired the geology holdings and the zoology collections were housed in the building known as Three Dragons Castle. Over the years, the Museum has added other collections, assembled through the efforts of individuals, collection campaigns, research, and occasional acquisitions. All of this has led to the impressive holdings that today provide material for research and public exhibitions.

column2: Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory
column15: Vertebrate, invertebrate, fossil and mineral specimen collections. The institution also holds collections in anthropology, archaeology, maritime history, Northern Territory history and the arts.

The Natural History Museum of the city of Geneva (MHNG) is the largest museum of natural history in Switzerland, both because of its wide public exhibition areas (permanent and temporary) and because of the size and historical importance of its scientific collections. The research activities reflect the diversity of the eight scientific departments and their collections, which cover most group of invertebrates and vertebrates, extant and fossils, archeozoology, mineralogy and geology. With very active fieldwork schedule on most continents, research at the museum includes comprehensive taxonomic revisions, new taxa descriptions, annotated faunistic lists, phylogeny and phylogeography studies (both morphological and molecular based). These researches are crucial for the understanding and protection of the biodiversity, in Switzerland and world while. Several projects are financed yearly by national or international funds, including the Swiss National Science Foundation, Switzerland's foremost institution in the promotion of scientific research. Meetings and congress are often organized at the museum, and students from several universities receive a complete scientific training in systematic and taxonomy at the museum, based on collection studies and molecular techniques conducted at the museum's own laboratory. Based on its long tradition on the study of bats in Switzerland, the museum houses the Swiss Bat Center which coordinates the protection and study of bats in West Switzerland and holds a large bibliographic database. On top of their scientific activities, all researchers at the museum are involved periodically in the conceptions and renovations of permanent and temporary exhibits.

column15: Te Papa's entomology team has an active research programme that includes describing new species, updating previous taxonomic treatments of particular spider groups, aquatic beetles and parasitic insects, as well as studying the geographical and phylogenetic relationships of parasitic insects with their hosts. Te Papa holds the principal collections of several entomological collectors: C. Fenwick (moths and flies); W.G. Howes (moths); G.V. Hudson (mainly moths, butterflies and beetles, but also other groups); J.H. Lewis (moths and beetles); A.C. O'Connor (beetles); J.T. Salmon (moths, stick-insects and springtails); H.W. Simmonds (Pacific Islands insects); M.N. Watt (leaf-mining insects); F. Chambers (wasps); T.H. Davies (Hawke's Bay insects and foreign butterflies); K.J. Fox (moths); and M.J. Meads (wetas and beetles).

column2: Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, University of California Berkeley
column15: The Museum of Vertebrate Zoology (MVZ) is a natural history museum at the University of California, Berkeley. The museum was founded in 1908, and houses over 700,000 specimens of amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. It is one of the largest research collections in the &nbsp;USA. In addition to traditional specimens, the MVZ houses large collections of tissue samples, audio recordings, and archival materials (e.g., field notes, photogrpaphs, correspondence).&nbsp;

column15: The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) will collect data across the United States on the impacts of climate change, land use change and invasive species on natural resources and biodiversity. NEON is a project of the U.S. National Science Foundation, with many other U.S. agencies and NGOs cooperating. NEON will be the first observatory network of its kind designed to detect and enable forecasting of ecological change at continental scales over multiple decades. The data NEON collects will be freely and openly available to all users.

column2: North Carolina State University Insect Museum
column15: Our holdings are partitioned into four main collections (all specimens use the same numbering system and do not require collection codes): NC State University Insect Collection - the vast majority of our specimens are housed here in the research collection Genome Bank - our cold storage collection for specimens used in molecular analyses NC State University Teaching Collection - approximately 60 drawers of insects used in our insect systematics course (ENT 502) NC State University Outreach Collection - approximately 8 drawers used for outreach ~1,400,000 prepared specimens. Holdings of North Carolina insects and of Hemiptera are especially outstanding. The NCSU Insect Collection has several other outstanding research collections (mainly Lepidoptera, Acari, Anthophila (the bees), Diptera, Coleoptera, Heteroptera, Orthoptera, and Collembola) within it and associated assemblages of literature that are of international importance.

column15: The Ocean Genome Legacy Center of New England Biolabs is a non-profit organization within Northeastern University, dedicated to creating a global biobank housing the DNA blueprints (genomes) of a broad cross-section of the endangered organisms of the sea. Our aim is to preserve and provide access to this global genomic legacy, and so to support understanding and protection of our planets greatest ecosystem. OGL archives three separate types of material (tissue samples, genomic DNA, and bacterial strains), but each has an ID within a different series unique prefixed numbers. Collection codes are therefore not necessary, as OGL:E00001 is distinct as is from OGL:St00001.

column15: Queensland's primary state repository for zoological collections (biodiversity and geosciences), in addition to cultures and histories. Zoological collections of living fauna are located at South Bank in Brisbane, and at the Museum of Tropical Queensland in Townsville. These include dry, alcohol preserved and frozen whole specimens; skeletal preparations; a minus 80 degrees tissue library; and DNA extracts. It includes:  about 2.5 million specimens or specimen lots of the living fauna; and an irreplaceable collection of over 34,000 type specimens (primary and secondary types), of the living animal species from Queensland and adjacent Indo-Pacific regions. The University of Queensland Insect Collection is now housed at the Queensland Museum. Collections of fossils and minerals are located in Brisbane at Hendra currently consisting of over 7 million fossil specimens, 55,000 geological samples, 27,000 mineral samples, and type specimen holdings of nearly 10,000 primary types.

The herbarium also houses smaller holdings of bryophytes and fungi, and a growing lichen collection. Sixty-five percent of the collection represents the flora of the grassland biome of central North America. The herbarium also contains a library of 1,400 books and 14,000 scientific articles, and a collection of more than 50,000 photographic slides and digital images.

column2: South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity
column15: The South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity is the custodian of the National Fish Collection of South Africa. The collection consists of about 90 000 lots of fish specimens (containing at least 650 000 individual fish specimens) from southern Africa and surrounding oceans, and from elsewhere in the world. It is the world's largest collection of southern African fishes. As well as adult and larval specimens preserved in propanol and ethanol (the vast majority), the collection and associated material consists of preparations of genetic material, cleared and stained preparations, dry skins and skeletons, otoliths, radiographs, photographs, drawings and paintings of fishes. About 7500 species in about 400 families are represented in the collection, depending on which classification is used. Frog specimens, in a different collection, are now also cataloged in a single numbering sequence with fish specimens without the need for collection codes.
column16: South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity
column23: South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity

column15: The Station Biologique de Roscoff (SBR) is a marine biology and oceanology research and teaching center. Various research groups work on a wide range of topics, ranging from investigation of the fine structure and function of biological macromolecules to global oceanic studies. Genomic approaches constitute an important part of many of the research programmes, notably via the European Network of Excellence "Marine Genomics" which is coordinated by the SBR.

Internationally-acclaimed scientists work in interdisciplinary research teams in chemistry, microbial ecology, invertebrate biology, watershed ecology, and ecosystem modeling to study the physical, chemical, and biological processes of streams and rivers, the life histories of individual organisms, and the ecology of watersheds. The Center's educational programs seek to disseminate the findings of the research projects, serve as a resource for science teachers, and enhance the stewardship of watersheds. Specimens are not cataloged with collection codes, but are divided into three groupings: 1.

column2: Swedish Museum of Natural History - Zoological Collections
column15: The Swedish Museum of Natural History is a major research institute that combines a venerable tradition with modern working methods. Our collections comprising almost ten millions of specimens, constitute an amazing archive of the natural world and our research laboratories are of world-class. The research staff at the museum collaborate with colleagues all over the world, and we receive many guest researchers every year. Collaboration in four fundamental reseach themes allow us to combine our specialist knowledge in different fields and obtain in this way increased understanding of the development and diversity of the Earth and the life on it. One of our specialties is systematics and phylogeny, i. e. research on the tree of life. Each year the recent past, the Research Division has participated in over 200 scientific publications, discovered over 100 new species and has welcomed over 500 visiting scientists from around the world.

Ulyanowski - 5000 units, Collection S.K. Pietrusky - 7460 units.  The museum preserves more than 130 type specimens of animals, that is, those which were first discovered and described to science. They come from the Ukraine, Russia, Poland, Brazil, India, Mexico, Australia, Eastern and Central Africa, the countries of Central Europe.

The Children's Hospital at Westmead's Tumor Bank is an invaluable resource for medical researchers from around the world studying childhood cancer. Samples of cancerous tumors are taken from consenting patients and placed into long term storage where they are then made available for research purposes. The ultimate aim is to improve prevention, diagnosis and treatment for children with cancer. Collection includes solid tumours specimens, whole blood, bone marrow (both whole and dried onto slides), serial leukaemia specimens as well as cerebral spinal fluid and plasma samples. Tissue samples are transferred to cryovials, snap frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80Â°C. All specimens are cataloged in a single numbering system and do not require collection codes.

column2: The Culture Collection of Algae at the University of Texas Austin
column15: The Culture Collection includes approximately 3,000 different strains of living algae, representing most major algal taxa. The primary function of UTEX is to provide algal cultures at modest cost to a user community. Cultures in the Collection are used for research, teaching, biotechnology development, and various other projects throughout the world. Most of the strains are kept under a numerical order system that require no prefixes, but there are four collections that use the prefixes SP, EE, FD, and SNO.

column15: The major collection of animal parasites in North America. It is one of the world's largest parasite collections and is the major repository of helminth type specimens for North American parasitologists. Although helminths are the largest group in the collection, other groups include parasitic protozoans, pentastomes, lice, mites, ticks, and other miscellaneous parasites. Many of the parasites were collected during USDA survey and eradication programs. About half of the specimens are stored in small bottles in a solution of 92 parts 70 percent ethanol, 3 parts formalin, and 5 parts glycerine. The others are mounted permanently on glass microscope slides. Specimens cataloged in a single collection without collection codes.

column2: Universidad de Navarra, Museum of Zoology
column15: The Museum of Zoology was established in 1980 to curate the scientific research materials of the Department of Zoology at the University of Navarra. Its climate-controlled storage facilities hold more than two million specimens, including several type series. Electronic files are in use since 1981. The in-house database system, Zootron V, currently manages more than 900.000 data records of the fauna collections. Like every other zoological research facility, the Museum of Zoology of the University of Navarra is open to world taxonomists wishing to consult its holdings. The Museum is a Data Provider for the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF) and is an Affiliate to the International Comission of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN). The Museum is also in charge of the curation and management of the Natural History Collections of the School of Science.

column15: Updated Jan 2010.  Since 1879 the Herbarium of the Department of Botany of the University of Coimbra, Portugal (COI), has owned the Herbarium of the german (Saxonian) Henrich Moritz Willkomm, Professor at Prague University and a specialist on the flora of the Iberian Peninsula. This collection was bought to Willkomm and contains vascular and non-vascular plants of the Mediterranean area and the Macaronesian Islands and includes c. 10.000 species and over 30.000 specimens. The specimens were collected by Willkomm himself and other relevant botanical collectors of the time e.g., Bourgeau, Orphanides, Sieber, Lange, Loscos, Boissier, Reuter, Lagasca, Cavanilles. It was the basis for Willkomm and Lange's Prodromus Florae Hispanicae (1861-1880), the first comprehensive Flora of most of the Iberian Peninsula - only now being superseded by the Flora iberica (Castroviejo et al., 1986-, Madrid) - and contains many type specimens of Iberian taxa. Not all Willkomm specimens are at COI and some are scattered in other institutes. But this is by far the largest assemblage of his material and he regarded it as his core collection which, as a whole he sold to Júlio Henriques, the founder of COI.  Specimens in Willkomm Herbarium not sent on loan.

column2: University of Colorado Museum of Natural History
column15: The University of Colorado Museum of Natural History houses the largest natural history collection in the Rocky Mountains. Currently, more than four million objects are categorized into five disciplines: Anthropology, Botany, Entomology, Paleontology, and Zoology. The collections include the world's oldest documented Navajo textile, the Aiken bird collection, and Colorado's largest collection of bees. Faculty and staff at the Museum conduct world-class research, using the extensive collections. Some of the current research at the Museum includes algal ecology of lakes and streams, the first colonization of the Americas, and coprolites and dinosaur diets.
column34: Organised into : Anthropology, Botany, Entomology, Paleobiology/Geology and Zoology.

column2: University of Connecticut Biodiversity Research Collections
column15: The Biodiversity Research Collections of the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at the University of Connecticut reflect the richness of the world's biodiversity. The vertebrate holdings consist of fish, bird and mammal collections, with a particularly strong emphasis on South American mammals. The invertebrate holdings focus on insects of New England, army ant 'guests' and parasites of Connecticut vertebrates and tapeworms from sharks and rays from around the world. In combination, the George Safford Torrey Herbarium and the EEB greenhouses maintain remarkable fossil, preserved and living plant collections with special concentrations in native New England plants and the region's imperiled and invasive species.

column15: Our mission is to explore, describe, and preserve representative specimens of Earth’s remarkable diversity of insects and to make these specimens available to the global community for research and education.  Contributions to the collection began in 1879 with specimens of insects and spiders from the North Shore of Lake Superior. During the last 135 years, the collection’s holdings have grown from a regional collection of 3,000 specimens to a major national and international resource of more than 3.8 million specimens. The collection is the mainstay of graduate training in systematic entomology at the University of Minnesota.

column2: National Zoological Gardens of South Africa
column15: The NZG Biobank acts as an integrated resource linking the multiple tissue collections (Tissue bank; DNA bank; Necropsy sample bank; Cell culture bank; Sperm bank) and provides samples and information to an interdisciplinary wildlife research and management audience regionally and globally.&nbsp; Sample providers include national and provincial parks, wildlife ranches and zoological institutions, while users include HEI&rsquo;s, research institutions, wildlife owners and others.&nbsp;  Through the Biobank, a single port of entry for organisations requiring African wildlife biomaterials for research, biodiversity conservation and biotechnology development purposes has been established. An advisory committee oversees operational efficiency and strategy. Members represented on the committee are experts drawn from the stakeholder community, biomaterial sample providers, sample users, academics, national and provincial regulatory authorities.&nbsp;  The NZG Biobank is housed in a dedicated building with offices, fully equipped laboratories for processing and cryo-preservation, storerooms, and multiple rooms with fridges, freezers ranging from 4 degrees C to minus 150 degrees C, to ultralow (liquid nitrogen) temperatures.  The Bank coordinates, collects, processes and stores different tissue types such as extracted DNA, ear-notches, hair, feathers, semen, organs etc. and maintains the samples under different and optimal storage conditions that are suitable for future research and management applications.&nbsp;

column15: Updated May 2012. NY diatoms transferred to CAS in 2002. Botanical library available to all researchers. Library includes over 260 400 volumes (105 000 book and monograph titles and nearly 11 000 serial titles), 125 000 reprints, collections of archives and manuscripts, seed catalogs and index semina, photographs, botanical art, and artifacts. The Library on-line catalog, is accessible  at: http://library.nybg.org. Services include interlibrary loan, photocopying, photography, CD-ROM database searches, and literature searches. Most services are for a fee. The Library is the repository for the Taxonomic Literature II (Stafleu and Cowan) data files and for the archives of the American Society of Plant Taxonomists, Council on Botanical and Horticultural Libraries, Mycological Society of America, Organization for Flora Neotropica, Society for Economic Botany, Torrey Botanical Society, and others.

The Zoological Collection of the University of Vienna is a scientific reference collection which covers almost the entire animal kingdom. It comprises an estimated 500.000 specimens which are worldwide in origin but with an emphasis on the territory of the former Austro-Hungarian Empire. Its resources include alcohol-preserved anatomical, embryological and whole-mount preparations, vertebrate and invertebrate skeletons as well as some rare and historic scientific models from Blaschka (glass models of marine animals), Fric, and Ziegler (wax models).

column15: The Australian Tropical Herbarium (ATH) is a joint venture of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), Director National Parks (DNP), Queensland Department of Environment and Resource Management (DERM), Queensland Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation (DEEDI), and James Cook University (JCU). The ATH boasts state-of-the-art facilities and infrastructure for specimen processing and curation, photography, pest and climate control, and field, herbarium and laboratory research. The main activity is management of the more than 160,000 plant specimens that comprise the CNS collection, a merger of the collections (and staff) of the Australian National Herbarium Atherton (QRS), the Queensland Herbarium Mareeba (MBA) and part of the JCU Herbarium collection (JCT) to form an unsurpassed representative collection of north Queensland's flora. Research at the Australian Tropical Herbarium covers a range of topics including tropical plant and fungal taxonomy and evolution, ethnobotany, ecology, climate change studies, development of identification products, agroforestry and regional ecosystem mapping. We currently have two numbering systems: one for DNA and one for all other collections (herbarium sheets, spirit, woodblocks). For non DNA specimens- CNS:12345 ; For DNA materials- CNS(DNA):12345 This will change once we revise the management of DNA materials; these will be databased according to the voucher specimen held in our main collection.

column15: Entered October 2012. ECWP herbarium is open to any researcher and amateur, by appointment, on request. However validation by the ECWP Operation Director is mandatory. The ECWP herbarium is located at ECWP headquarters in Missour, Morocco, in a building dedicated to botanical studies. Specimens are mounted on acid-free, archival paper (48 x 28 cm) and are stored in cardboard boxes, that are themselves in cabinets. Many vouchers have been verified by Mohammed Ibn Tattou (Institut Scientifique de Rabat), one of the authors of the Flore pratique du Maroc. There is an Excel file list of identified specimens vouchers. A software dedicated to sample collection management is planned for 2014. ECWP also has a botanical bibliographical collection, specializing in south-west Mediterranean flora and habitats, that includes 150 books and monographs and >4000 pdf files (books, monographs, papers). There is a flora/fauna database in the production for over three years, including over 1400 recent phytosociological relevés.

column15: Entered Oct 2010.  The Alfred Twining Herbarium is housed in two metal cabinets in the basement of the Everhart Museum.  The specimens are mounted on herbarium sheets or are loose in folders which are enclosed in additional folders and are arranged in a family sequence used by Alfred Twining in his  (1917).  Most of the specimens were collected by Twining in the early twentieth centure prior to the publication of the flora.  EMNH is the major repository for Twining specimens -- few are duplicated at PH.   However, most, if not all, of the Glowenke specimens (from the 1930s) are duplicated in PH (summarized from an assessment of the herbarium by A. Schuyler).  Supercedes EVMU.

column15: Entered May 2011.  This herbarium is based in the Ituri Forest. It has been developed to be a herbarium of reference for research in biodiversity and plant conservation, flora and tropical botany, forest ecology studies of DR Congo protected areas. ; ; The herbarium collection contains a number of endemic species and important collections of little-known areas of botanical diversity importance (Inselbergs and Edos (salines). ; ; It is the only herbarium devoted to the study of the DR Congo protected areas flora, and has been active in updating and providing recent collections from DR Congo during the last two decades. ; ; This herbarium is also active in developing a National Strategic Plan for Plants Conservation and working with IUCN for the Red Data Listing in DR Congo.

column15: Entered Feb 2013.  The Elizabeth Teter Lunn Herbarium is home to more than 5,000 plant specimens dating primarily from the turn of the twentieth century, with some being collected, purportedly, as early as 1848. Between the years 1895 and 1897. M.C. Jensen, a student and botanist, collected more than 80 specimens within the city of Lake Forest, IL, and added these to the College's collection.  At present, student Victoria Jones is in the process of writing a proposal for Lake Forest College to pay more attention to the collection and thus salvage this one-of-a-kind herbarium. This proposal reflects Victoria's senior-thesis topic and all of the tedious curatorial work she has committed to for the past three years. Victoria is currently working alongside Gerould Wilhelm, the foremost vascular plant botanist of the Chicago Region, to observe truth and beauty in each specimen of the ETL Herbarium. The outcome will be Gerould Wilhelm's and Laura Rericha's brand new book, Flora of the Chicago Region. This book will update Swink and Wilhelm's Plants of the Chicago Region (1994).
column33: The majority of the collection contains specimens from Illinois Beach State Park (IBSP) collected by Elizabeth Teter Lunn (professor at Lake Forest College) between the 1950s and mid-1970s. Lunn's interest in collecting from IBSP was based on an earlier study tallying the park's flora during the 1900s. The result was the publication of her guidebook, "Plants of the Illinois Dunesland," completed in 1982 and published by The Illinois Dunesland Preservation Society.

column15: Updated Dec 2013.  M. Guiry retired in 2009, and the algal materials (those of Guiry and Mairin De Valera)  are now in the Ryan Institute, National University of Ireland Galway. The small flowering plant herbarium is still at the Botany and Plant Science discipline of the School of Natural Sciences. The code  "GALW" applies to both collections. The algal herbarium has 15,500 numbered specimens; the flowering plants, mosses and lichen herbarium comprise 2,000- 3,000 specimens, of which the vascular plant collection is the greatest and is currently the only numbered collection. Most of the lichen collection was re-housed in DBN in 2001.

column33: All groups worldwide, especially Fennoscandia (incl. NW Russia) and other areas of boreal and temperate Europe, Asia and North America. Bryophytes and lichens also strong in collections from Japan, China, Australasia, New Guinea, Brazil, Argentina, Chile, and many other tropical areas. Fungi also strong in aphyllophoroid and agaricoid groups as well as in smut fungi, powdery mildews and mycetozoa. Other specialties include apomictic phanerogams (Hieracium, Taraxacum, Ranunculus auricomus agg.), Cyperaceae and Chenopodiaceae. Also collections of wood, seeds, cones, and cultivated ornamental plants, including those collected in Kaisaniemi and Kumpula Botanic Gardens.

column15: Entered Jan 2013.  The collections are recorded digitally in the : IrisBG database,Botanical Garden Collection Management.  Hoyt Arboretum and Herbarium is integral with the Portland Parks and Recreation (PPR) system. PPR manages 11,209 acres of parks with 7,593 acres being natural areas. PPR also employs ecologists and restoration biologists. I aspire to bring to PPR, Metro, Bureau of Environmental Services, Portland State U., and general public; through Hoyt Arboretum and Herbarium, access to our living collections and herbarium to create regional research opportunities as well as achieving greater taxonomic resolution in our parks natural areas. The Herbarium is ; creating invasive species teaching voucher collection for regional institution education programs.  Hoyt Arboretum research library is available to the above institutions and the public.

column15: Updated Mar 2015.  The Luis Diego Gomez Herbarium is located at the Las Cruces Biological Station (8° 47' 7'' N, 82° 57' 32'' W), one of three field stations owned and operated by the Organization for Tropical Studies (OTS; www.ots.cr) in Costa Rica.  This is a young herbarium (inaugurated 2006) but a comprehensive collection of the regional flora of southern Costa Rica is well underway, and all specimens are scanned and uploaded to the OTS plant database website (www.ots.cr/plantdatabase). The collecting is only ~1,400 km2 but spans an elevational gradient of 300 - 3200 m and a rainfall range from 1.5 - 5 m (see website for a map of collecting range).

column15: Entered Jan 2012.  The Herbarium of Mordovian State Nature Reserve was  initially all  stored in one plywood cabinet. The fungi, lichens and mosses were stored in thick paper bags in a special plywood box. Today the herbarium collections of vascular plants Mordovian State Nature Reserve has 3216 herbarium sheets in 7 wooden cabinets, each of which is divided into 10 chambers, arranged in two columns.  The specimens are  arranged in the Englerian system.  Most of the herbarium collections were made within the reserve and in adjacent territories. The herbarium reflects  the species diversity of flora in the west of Mordovia, with  756 species belonging to 377 genera and 99 families.  The macrofungus herbarium has about 1500 specimens and includes about 400 species. It is stored in plastic ziplock bags enclosed in kraft paper bags and is located on the system, adopted in  the 9th edition of Ainsworth and Bisbsy's Dictionary of the fungi. There are about  100 specimens of mosses, and about 700 specimens of lichens stored in cardboard boxes.

column15: updated Jan 2013 (staff, contact info update) .  The herbarium of Hazara University is located near the junction of three  world-famous mountain ranges: Hindukush, Himalaya and Karakorum. This area, spread over thousands of kilometers, has an altitudinal gradient raanging from  400m to world's tallest peaks including K2 (8611m), Nanga Parbat (8126m), Rakaposhi (7788m) and Tirich Mir (7690m)]. The area is famous for the Indus Valley, the rich cultural diversity of people and a great variety of biodiversity resources including diverse endemic flora, yet to be explored for its potential.; ; Herbarium Hazara University aims to document and resolve of related issues like threats of extinction to the endemic flora, extensive deforestation, habitat destruction, unmanaged grazing and urbanization etc.; ; Due to rich vegetation of its vicinity, Herbarium Hazara University can exchange enormous number of higher vascular plants and archegoniates of Western Himalaya throughout the world.

column15: Updated Sept 2011.   The Herbarium contains:;  1. Nomenclatural types: 2,897 ; 2. Historical: important collections made by Ducke (8,571 samples), Goeldi, A. (376 samples), Huber (2,500 samples), Snethlage, E. (257 samples),Spruce (396 samples), Tresling (92 samples), Ule (2,788 samples).; 3. Fungous and lichens: are represented by 3.895  specimens, including Basidiomycotinae, Ascomycotae, Myxomicotinae, and historical collections ; 4. Bryophytes: the herbarium houses 7,699 vouchers, which 96 are typus collected between 1889 and 1912 by Ernest H. Ule. ; 5. Ferns: 5,311 ; 6. Flowering Plants: the herbarium presents a collection of approximately 165,990 vouchers from Amazonia, South, Southern, Northeast and Central Brazil ; 7. Palms: 884 ; 8. Ethnobotany: 137; 9. Seedlings:  121 vouchesr, cataloged in Brahms. This type of collection is rare in Brazil, probably only MG and IAN (Embrapa Amazônia Oriental herbarium) have it, for each specimen of the seedling collection the respective voucher the regular collection is needed.; 10. Fruit and seed: with 3,128 specimens.; 11. Pollen: This collection  joins 2,245 microscope slides of Amazonian species.; 12. Histological: 700 microscope slides of vegetative organs (root, stem and leaves).; 13. Wood: holds ca.  7,814 vouchers and a slide collection of histological sections, specially from the Amazonian species.; 14. Essencial oils - 900 samples from Amazon plants.

column15: Entered Aug 2011.  It was through the efforts of Dr. Gavino C. Trono Jr. that this marine plants herbarium was established in the early 1970's.  The Marine Science Institute (then the Marine Sciences Center) provided the seed money.  The late Dr. Velasquez donated all his algal collections to this herbarium, thus it carried his name in acknowledgment of his generous contribution. The seagrass collection of Dr. Miguel D. Fortes was later added to the herbarium. It was Dr. Edna G. Fortes who computerized the herbarium starting in 1987 with funds from the International Development Research Centre of Canada.
column33: The herbarium houses about 1,100 species belonging to 500 genera of marine plants (about 96 % are marine benthic algae and 4% are seagrasses) collected from 70 countries; 93% are Philippine species.  The herbarium also contains PACSEA  (Pacific Seaboard Collection)

column2: Hugh Nicholson and Tony Abbott Herbarium
column15: Entered Nov 2011.  The Hugh Nicholson and Tony Abbott Herbarium is a field based collection of the flora of the Pondoland Center of Endemism (PCE) which, in turn, forms part of the Maputaland-Pondoland-Albany which is one of the 25 global biodiversity hotspot identified by Conservation International. The herbarium is housed in the Umtamvuna Nature Reserve, a protected area managed by the provincial nature conservation agency, Ezemvelo KwaZulu-Natal Wildlife, and is staffed by local volunteer Honorary Officers. For continuity, the first point of contact is the Ezemvelo KwaZulu-Natal Wildlife District Ecologist for the Central and South portion of the East Region of the Province. From there your correspondence will be directed to the relevant person(s) to deal with your query.

column15: The botanical legacy collection of Mr. Peter Alexander Smith (P.A. Smith) forms the core of PSUB herbarium collection. It represents plants from northern Botswana, in particular the Okavango delta a Ramsar site which was also declared the 1000th world heritage site in 2014.   Other collectors represented within the collection include: D.T.Williamson (whose focus was in the Kalahari), G.E.Gibbs-Russell, G.V.Pope, H. Hiemstra, H.M.Beagle, M.J.Owens, R. C. Biggs (collecting as part of his MA on Chief's Island in the 1970s), T. Muller and W. L. Astle.  Duplicate specimens from P. A. Smith and many of these collectors are cited in Flora Zambesiaca for species distribution in Botswana.

column15: Entered Jul 2011.  The herbarium was established shortly after the founding of the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory (RMBL), in 1929 by Harriet G. Barclay from the University of Tulsa (TULS). It has served as a resource for plant identification and distribution information for students and researchers at the lab and contains vouchers from many research projects over the past 80 years. The collection is completely databased and searchable online at:; http://rmbl.org/herbarium/index1.html .; The laboratory/field station, located at over 9500 ft.in the Elk Mountains of Western Colorado, is open and accessible seasonally from May-October. The collection is curated by volunteers from other institutions who work at the lab each summer (currently C.F. Rick Williams, Curator, Ray J. Davis Herbarium [IDS], Idaho Museum of Natural History; and George Weiblen, Assistant Curator of Vascular Plants, Bell Museum of Natural History [MIN], University of Minnesota).

column15: Entered Dec 2011. Sagehen Creek Field Station is approximately 8000 acres, and encompasses a diverse cross section of the Sierra Nevada from the Pacific Crest (el. 8000 ft) to the eastern slope (el. 6400 ft). Habitats include yellow pine, mixed conifer, and red fir forests, as well as brushfields, scattered mountain meadows, and fens.
column33: The Sagehen Herbarium is comprised of two related collections: "Herbarium of the Sagehen Creek Field Station" and "Flora of California."  The Sagehen Creek collection is fairly comprehensive of plants found on the reserve.  The "Flora of California" collection draws from a broader area, but is still focused on Sierra Nevada specimens.

column15: Updated Jan 2013 (address):   We are pleased to inform you that custom problems were solved by our Institution and therefore we can receive loans, safe and secure, at our traditional address. Also, we would like to comment that for the reception of packages of plants being sent to our Institution, as loans, return loans, exchanges and gifts, the Custom agents request that a phytosanitary certificate be mailed, according  to quarantine restrictions that here apply for herbarium material. So we would be grateful if a  copy of the phytosanitary certificate be sent, by email, prior to the shipment of the specimens. Finally, the shipment/s of botanical specimens should be sent by regular mail, i.e. not by private couriers (such as FedEx, DHL and so on).  SI contains more than 135 000 specimens, including 1000 types, 2400 periodicals, 8500 books, and the updated checklist of vascular plants can be viewed on the SI web page.

column15: A present, the herbarium has more than 30,000 flowering plant specimens (including 155 wet orchid specimens), 1660 fern specimens, 700 moss specimens, 100 liverworts specimens and 1235 marine algal specimens.  The collections focus mainly on the vascular and bryophyte floras of Singapore and Malaysia. Important collections include the 255 sheets of grass specimens annotated by Hamish Boyd Gilliland and the 100 moss specimens collected by Anne Johnson.  Recently, Ian Mark Turner donated 2,500 voucher specimens of his collections cited in his floristic publications of selected localities in Malaya and Singapore. Other collectors of specimens preserved at SINU are Hsuan Keng, James Franklin Maxwell, Wee Yeow Chin, Jumali bin Kafrawi, Haji Samsuri bin Haji Ahmad, Hugh Tan Tiang Wah and Benito Ching Tan.

column15: Updated Jun 2012.  Details of Magnus Spence's Herbarium are now online: http://www.orkneycommunities.co.uk/STROMNESSMUSEUM/library.asp; A summary following a recent cataloguing exercise (which produced the herbarium list accessible at the above link) is:; Magnus Spence (1853-1919) assembled his herbarium collection in the late Nineteenth and very early Twentieth Centuries. The number of specimens in the herbarium is 918, comprising 556 species of vascular plants, seven algae and five bryophytes. The original total certainly included two further species of vascular plant, each represented by a single specimen.

column15: Entered Jul 2010.  The Herbarium of the Universidade Federal do Acre (UFACPZ) was founded in 1979.  Much of the collection is the product of a collaborative research program with The New York Botanical Garden (NY).  UFACPZ exchanges specimens with major Brazilian herbaria and with herbaria in neighboring Peru and Bolivia.  As of 2010 the entire collection is being imaged and data-based using BRAHMS.  The data stored in the Herbarium UFACPZ are of priority use for educational, scientific and public management. No aspect of this collection may be used without proper legal permission for any commercial purpose or one that generates income

column15: Updated Nov 2011. FI includes the following herbaria: General Herbarium, which incorporates Herbarium Centrale Italicum (~ 3 800 000 specimens) and to which belong Herbarium Libycum (15 000 specimens) and Herbarium Cryptogamicum (780 000 specimens); separate historical herbaria: Herbarium Webbianum (FI-W; 300 000 specimens), Herbarium Beccarianum-Malesia (FI-B; 16 000 specimens), Herbarium Beccari Palmae (FI-BP; 6700 specimens), and Herbarium Michelianum (FI-M; 18 366 specimens).  The Botanical Section also includes historical herbaria such as A. Cesalpino, 16th century, M. Merini, 16th century, A. Coltellini, 18th century, and wax and gypsum plant models of 18th and 19th century. On September 22nd, 2009 the Pteridological Herbarium of Professor R.E.G. Pichi Sermolli (1912-2005) was incorporated. Professor Pichi Sermolli, a worldwide known pteridologist, left a rich herbarium of 25,000 specimens including much type material and a specialized library of 450 books and 7,000 reprints. Professor Pichi Sermolli's herbarium is referred to by us as FI-PS, since it is a special collection of FI. Any request should be sent to the usual address of FI:; ; ; This precious collection is available to all interested researchers and specialists after prior arrangement; due to the historical significance and uniqueness of the a collections,  loan is possible only through digital images. it is now possible to consult the data base archive of  the Herbarium Centrale Italicum (FI) for the Italian specimens.; The data base gives the full scientific name, the occurrence of types, any reference to synonyms, floristic records, literature, etc. and the names of Italian regions the specimens come from.; Obviously the archive is  "in progress", in the sense that it will be regularly updated. ; It is also possible to request loans of the specimens directly, clicking on "Loan request".; The loan is made only to Institutions registered for the Index Herbariorum.;  ; To consult this data base, go to the web address of the Natural History Museum of Florence www.msn.unifi.it, click on "Botanical Section Herbaria" http://parlatore.msn.unifi.it and then on HCI ITALY WEB.
column33: All groups worldwide, especially Italy and Mediterranean area.

column15: updated Jul 2012.  ; ; Loans: Types not sent on loan.; ; History and specificity:; ; Initiated at the beginning of the 19th century, now with about 250 000 samples, this collection reflects: 1) the history of Marseille: port open to the world, especially to the former French overseas territories and 2) the competence and influence of the 19th century Provençal naturalists. Today this herbarium includes: currently active herbaria, historical collections of the 19th and the 20th century of the South-East of the France and various herbaria relating to France's colonial history.; ; Currently active herbaria: 1) a general world herbarium of vascular plants initiated by Louis Castagne in 1820, 2) a general herbarium of vascular plants of France, 3) a general herbarium of vascular plants of the French Mediterranean area, 4) a cytogenetic herbarium of plants mainly collected and studied by J. Contandriopoulos and R. Verlaque, 5) a general world herbarium of lichen and 6) a general world herbarium of bryophyte.; Historical and prestigious collections of the 19th and the 20th century of the South-East of the France, corresponding to the first "modern" flora : 1) Herbier Louis Castagne (Catalogue des plantes qui croissent naturellement dans le département des Bouches-du-Rhône), 2) Honoré Ardoino (Flore analytique du département des Alpes-maritimes), 3) Honoré Roux (Catalogue des plantes de Provence spontanées ou généralement cultivées)� Various herbaria relating to France's colonial history : 1) Herbier Père Antoine Duss des Antilles (Flore phanérogamique des Antilles françaises, Guadeloupe et Martinique), 2) Herbier Henri Jumelle and Henri Perrier de la Bathie for Madagascar (numerous publications among the Catalogue des plantes de Madagascar), 3) Herbier Eugène Jacob de Cordemoy for La Réunion (Flore de l'Ile de la Réunion), used for the " Flore des Mascareignes ", 4) Herbier Georg. Zenker (Cameroun), Herbier Boery (Mauritanie) for the " Afrique Orientale Française ", 5) Herbier Pennel and Metzger for the Nouvelle Calédonie.; ; Moreover, the botanical collections of the University include the Musée Colonial de Marseille founded in 1893 as a part of the Institut Colonial de Marseille. This collection contains plant samples from overseas selected and used for food (fruits, vegetables, cereals, oils, etc.), as condiments and spices, for pharmaceuticals and for industry (rubber, wood, fibres, etc.).

column15: Updated Sep 2012.  The Herbarium of the Arkansas Natural Heritage Commission consists primarily of specimens collected in the course of statewide ecological and biological inventory work conducted by the Arkansas Natural Heritage Program.  Many of the specimens represent species that are rare in the state or were collected from rare or unusual habitats.  The goals of the collection are 1) to provide a reference collection for work performed by Natural Heritage Commission staff and their conservation partners, 2) to house voucher specimens for rare plant records in the database of the Arkansas Natural Heritage Program, and 3) to voucher plants of ecologically sensitive or otherwise significant lands, including those contained within the State's System of Natural Areas.  While most specimens are from Arkansas, special care is being made to assemble a collection of plants from surrounding states that are not presently known in Arkansas but are likely to be found there

column15: Updated April 2013.  B.A. Bennett Herbarium contains only Vascular Plants. With nearly 5000 Yukon specimens it is one of the largest and most comprehensive collections of vascular plants from the Territory. Visiting researchers and students are encouraged to use the herbaria. The library includes all significant northern floras including floras of Russian, Scandinavia, Europe, Canada and the Pacific Northwest. Additional resources include over 4000 reprints primarily of literature relevant to the Yukon flora, including many historical account. Significant exchanges are currently made with UBC, ALA, CAN, DAO and to a lesser extent ALTA and WTU.
column33: Vascular plants of Yukon Territory, but Beringian and Circumboreal flora are also highlighted. Additional significant holdings of collections include Alaska, British Columbia, Manitoba, Ontario and Northwest Territories.

Formerly listed under BANGKOK; ; Description of the fungus herbarium:; The BIOTEC Fungal Herbarium was established in 1996 and was registered with Index Herbariorum in 2003. The herbarium has been housed in a purpose-built temperature/humidity controlled facility since 2003. The facility holds 40+ type specimens. Of the 20000+ specimens almost half represent insect fungi. Other major groups include Basidiomycetes (especially Marasmius and Mycena and allied genera) and Xylariales.

column33: ; ; Despcription of the plant herbarium:; The BIOTEC Plant Herbarium is managed by the Ecology and Geo-informatics Lab, and specializes in storing and distributing voucher specimens from the biodiversity research plots established by the Lab. Its main plot is the 30-ha forest dynamics plot in Khao Yai National Park. Voucher specimens from other research projects within BIOTEC and outside collaborators are also stored.

column15: The Natural History Museum of the Grisons is a centre of information on natural science. Its various activities present the nature and the characteristics of the canton Grisons to the broad public. A major aspect of the activities is documenting the nature of the Grisons and its changes. The rich collections and its own research suit this purpose.  Collections  The collections are the core of the museum and indispensable for science. Most objects of the collections come from Grisons. The oldest collections are 200 years old. Others were built up a short time ago and have been supplemented continuously. Especially worth mentioning are the collections from the Swiss National Park and the one of mammals.  Botany: The collection of vascular plants is extensive. The so-called &ldquo;Herbarium Raeticum&rdquo; covers examples of vascular plants collected in Graub&uuml;nden within the last 200 years. World-famous Josias Braun-Blanquet (1884-1980), a pioneer of plant ecology, had a herbarium of his own in his parental home in Chur. This herbarium is at the Natural History Museum of the Grisons, while his other herbariums are stored at the University of Montpellier. The oldest herbarium of the Museum was collected at the beginning of the 19th century by the B&uuml;ndner pastor Luzius Pool.  Zoology: Since the foundation of the museum mammals have been continuously collected. And since 1970 small mammals (rodents, insectivores, small carnivores) have been systematically sampled. This collection is one of the most extensive in the whole area of the Alps. Various collections from the Swiss National Park as well as the collection of butterflies by Thomann and the collection of snails by Wolf are scientifically significant. Recent collections are those of wild bees and butterflies.  Geology: The geological collections include many special pieces collected by well-known B&uuml;ndner geologists. The rock collection of big tunnel constructions in Grisons is outstanding. On display there are fossils from the region of the Swiss National Park, the region of Piz Aela (fish saurian) and relicts of fish saurian from the Ducan area near Davos. Fragments of cave bear bones &ndash; between 50&#39;000 and 100&#39;000 years old &ndash; were found in the caves of Sulzfluh near St. Ant&ouml;nien.  &nbsp;

column15: Entered May 2009.  The Clark Herbarium serves as a reference library to the plant diversity and changes of Southern California.   With almost 10,000 specimens, the Clark Herbarium includes dry botanical mounts, most of which were collected from the Riverside region and surrounding counties by J. C. Roos and other botanists between 1920 and 1990. A small collection of lichens and fungi was assembled during the 1930s by Edmund C. Jaeger, and was later donated to the Museum during his tenure as Curator of Plants. All these materials now represent an important database describing the distribution of native plant species in the southwestern U.S., which is now a vastly altered environmental setting.

column15: The University of Washington Fish Collection is a state-supported facility that is part of the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture located on the University of Washington campus in Seattle. &nbsp;Fish Collection staff and resources play an important role in undergraduate and graduate education within the School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences, and our school outreach program is very popular. We also provide a variety of tours for other interested parties, and field many telephone inquiries from the press and public concerning mysterious fishes and other ichthyological matters.  Our primary mission is to support teaching and research in the areas of ichthyology, fisheries biology, aquatic biology, conservation, and biodiversity, and to provide a source of ichthyological information for the public. We maintain a large archival collection of preserved fishes from the Pacific Northwest and around the world, and we make this valuable material available for study both to visitors in the collection and through a program of gifts, loans, and exchanges.

column15: The Zoological Museum of the University of Athens is the oldest and richest zoological museum of Greece. It is part of the National Natural History Museum that is the oldest natural history museum in the eastern Mediterranean and the Balkans.&nbsp;    	The collections of the Museum include: approximately 500 small and large mammals from Greece, Europe and other continents, stuffed or as skeletons. 2500 birds from Greece, together with eggs and nests. A large collection of approximately 1000&nbsp;&nbsp;reptiles, amphibians and fish of Greece and other parts of the world. Insects and mollusks together with other invertebrates such as sponges, crustaceans, corals etc. Last but not least the Museum collections contain a large number of anthropological material, mainly skulls, some of which show paleopathological symptoms.  	  		&nbsp;    &nbsp;

The Illinois Natural History Survey&rsquo;s Biological Collections include more than 9.5 million specimens housed in ten separate collections. All collections except the birds collection and the mammals collection rank within the 15th largest in North America. &nbsp;These collections, some of which date back over 150 years, represent the most complete record of Illinois biota anywhere. &nbsp;Most collections are also global in geographic coverage for many groups.  Because these specimens document the presence of species through time, our collections are an invaluable resource for tracking changes in species distributions as habitats have been modified. &nbsp;The collections are regularly used in scientific research to recognize threatened and endangered species, determine the arrival and spread of exotic and invasive species, provide baseline data for ecological restoration projects, evaluate habitat quality over time and space, assess the effects of climate change, locate populations of medical or economic importance, resolve evolutionary relationships, discover new species, and facilitate species identification through comparative morphology and DNA barcoding. &nbsp;Many specimen records are available online through web-based searchable databases accessible to scientists, resource managers, policy makers, and the public.

column15: National Center for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology (BIOTEC) founded BIOTEC Culture Collection (BCC) in 1996. The primary objective of BCC is to collect and maintain microorganisms and their relevant data deposited by BIOTEC researchers and distribute for BIOTEC&rsquo;s in-house research. Microorganisms in BCC are routinely tested by BIOTEC researchers to find valuable products. Besides the maintenance and distribution of microorganisms for in-house research, BCC provides such services as well as training, identification, and lyophilization services to public.

column15: The Delaware Museum of Natural History&#39;s research collections have a strong emphasis on birds and mollusks (shells), reflecting the original collecting interests of our founder, John E. du Pont. We also have smaller collections of mammals, insects, and plants.  The bird collection consists of approximately 67,000 study skins, 9,000 skeletons, and 36,000 clutches of eggs. We also maintain a small tissue collection containing samples from eastern North American taxa. &nbsp;The collection, worldwide in scope, has especially strong collections of Philippine and Central and South American birds. The holdings represent about 4,000 bird species. About 140 taxa are in the type collection.&nbsp;&nbsp;  The Museum&#39;s&nbsp;mollusk collection consists of more than 2 million specimens, making it one of the top twelve in the United States. The 220,000 cataloged lots represent more than 18,000 species. Worldwide in scope and covering all seven living classes of mollusks, our holdings comprise marine Gastropoda (50%), land and freshwater Gastropoda (25%), marine Bivalvia (15%), and freshwater Bivalvia (5%). The Museum&#39;s mollusk collection is primarily dry shells, with some alcohol preserved cephalopod specimens.&nbsp; Most specimens are recent; however there is some&nbsp;Cenozoic fossil material. Our type collection contains more than 1,200 lots.&nbsp;  The mammal collection consists of approximately 6,000 specimens (skins, skulls, &amp; skeletons). About half of the collection is Philippine bats and rodents, most collected by D.S. Rabor; the remaining half is North American mammals.&nbsp;  The insect collection contains approximately 1,500 specimens primarily from eastern North America.&nbsp;  The herbarium contains nearly 400 specimens, primarily from the eastern United States and mostly collected since 1980.

column2: UOA/HCPF University of Athens/Hellenic Collection of Pathogenic Fungi
column14: Medical research institute, including hospitals, medical schools
column15: The collection complies with the UN directive on biological diversity as ratified by 150/161 member states (Cartagena protocol; ratified by Greece 24/05/2000).  Aims of the collection are: (a) To preserve and sustain human pathogenic fungi in a metabolic attenuated condition in order to safeguard biodiversity and promote taxonomic, physiological molecular, proteomic and metabolomic studies at a local and international level; (b) promote exchange of strains with other Culture Collections, educational and research institutions; (c) provide locally consultative service for accurate characterization of clinical fungi; (d) organize educational events, such as workshops small group tutorials, for health professionals, veterinarians, scientists and clinical scientists at a national and international level. &nbsp;  Mission: To sustain and increase resources and infrastructure for the ex-situ preservation of fungi, advance and promote the sciences relevant to fungal pathobiology and virulence through education, advocacy, and scholarly exchange of scientific information.  Services: All provided services and a catalogue of phenotypically and molecularly identified clinical filamentous fungi and yeasts, available for research and educational purposes, are published in the WDCM site (http://www.wfcc.info/ccinfo/index.php/collection/by_id/929&nbsp;). All requests for stains are accompanied by singing MTA agreement, available in English, as recently approved by the Legal Department of the Athens University.  Expertise: &nbsp;As conveyed by the publication records (Scopus and PubMed). Briefly, taxonomy, pathobiology, immunology, pharmacology, infectious diseases fungal metabolites with biological activity.  Other:    	  		(http://www.isham.org): &nbsp;coordination of global working groups on fungal epidemiology, organization of educational events in Mycology.  	  		The Collection is a European training site for public health Microbiology (EUPHEM), The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).

column2: University of Alberta Microfungus Collection and Herbarium
column14: Living Organism Collection (e.g., culture collection, cell lines)
column15: &nbsp;The University of Alberta Microfungus Collection and Herbarium (UAMH) is a Canadian fungal repository involved in collection, conservation, distribution, education and research on living fungi of medical, scientific, industrial and heritage importance. Living cultures are backed up by herbarium specimens.  Significant collections include:  	Fungi associated with human and animal disease including pathogenic, opportunistic, allergenic and toxic fungi. &nbsp;  	Plant root associated endophytes and mycorrhizal symbionts of woody, ericaceous and orchidaceous plants especially from boreal habitats.  	Environmental fungi causing stain and decay or problems in the built environment.  	Insect associated fungi including large collections of Ophiostomatales associated with mountain pine and other bark beetles.  	Significant collections of fungi belonging to the Onygenales, Eurotiales, Microascales, Leotiomycetes (Ascomycota).  	Fungi tested for biodegradation or bioremediation properties.

column15: The acronym ZIHU to refer to the invertebrate collection at the former Zoological Institute, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, began to be used since 1985, while the same acronym exists that stands for Zoological Institute, Hiroshima University, Higashi-hiroshima. column15: The NIAS (National Institute of Agrobiological Sciences) Genebank is the central coordinating institute in Japan for conservation of plants, microorganisms, animals and DNA materials related to agriculture. The NIAS Genebank coordinates this activity in collaboration with a network of institutes throughout Japan.  The NIAS Genebank actively participates in collaborative activities with other countries in relation to surveys and research related to agricultural related genetic resources. In all activities related to conservation of genetic resources the NIAS Genebank follows the international community norms and national regulations. Plant and microorganism germplasm within the NIAS Genebank system collected in Japan is available for research purposes.  For scientists interested in germplasm related to agriculture within the NIAS Genebank system they are directed to the databases that follow that provide full details of how to request materials in each category of genetic resource.  The databases of the NIAS Genebank that can be found at this web site include information on passport data, evaluation as well as more general information on genetic resources.

column15: The Zoology Unit, a part of the Finnish Museum of Natural History, is a scientific research unit specializing on animal species diversity. The research includes studies on systematics, taxonomy, zoogeography as well as faunal surveys and monitoring projects.  The Zoology Unit takes care of the scientific collections of the Zoological Museum, which currently comprise about nine million animal specimens and samples. Tens of thousands of specimens are added every year. The collections are primarily used in research of animal taxonomy and systematics, and also for teaching purposes and environmental studies.

column15: Zoological Collection  The Zoological Museum Hamburg (ZMH) is one of the most important natural-history-research museums in Germany. The ZMH has earned its high national and international reputation owing to its collection and research output. The collection as the heart of the museum includes approximately 10 million zoological objects and therefore forms the fourth largest of its kind in Germany. The collection constitutes the main basis for efficient research performed by the staff of the ZMH at the University of Hamburg. Here the ZMH and the Zoological Institute cooperate in research and teaching very closely with each other.
